Service - Processing - Caching - Strateg: Lazy Loading. First checks the cache. If data is found (a cache hit) use it. If not found (a cache miss), retrieves from database and store in cache.
When data is updated, it is written to the cache and the database simultaneously.
Data is written to the cache first and then to the database 'asynchronously.
Bypasses the cache for writes, writing directly to the database. The cache is updated only on subsequent reads.
The cache acts as data loader. If data isn't in the cache, it's retrieved from the database and stored in the cache.
The cache proactively refreshes data before it expires.

CI - Packaging - CodeReduction - Paginat: Pagination is a common optimization technique when result sets are large. By streaming results back to the client in pages, service responsiveness can be improved.
This technique uses an offset and a limit parameter to define the starting point and the number of records to return. Example: GET /orders?offset=0&limit=3
This technique uses a cursor (a unique identifier) to mark the position in the dataset. Typically, the cursor is an encoded string that points to a specific record. Example: GET /orders?cursor=xxx
This technique specifies the page number and the size of each page. Example: GET /items?page=2&size=3
This technique uses a key to filter the dataset, often the primary key or another indexed column. Example: GET /items?after_id=102&limit=3
This technique uses a timestamp or date to paginate through records. Example: GET /items?start_time=xxx&end_time=yyy
This technique combines multiple pagination techniques to leverage their strengths. Example: Combining cursor and time-based pagination for efficient scrolling through time-ordered records.
